awd_titl_txt: ODOMATIC: Automatic Species Identification, Functional Morphology, and Feature Extraction to alleviate the taxonomic impediment and broaden citizen science tools.
awd_abstract_narration:
The naming and classifying of living organisms is a fundamental principal upon which biology is founded. Indeed, almost every facet of our lives - from the food we eat to the medicine we take, the houses we live in to the natural scenery we admire - has a connection to the biodiversity present on Earth. All species must be named and cataloged in order for humans to understand the world around us. The scientific field of taxonomy, responsible for identifying and describing species, has incurred a reduction in its specialist workforce in recent decades; this is unfortunate because the need for taxonomy has never been greater as human activities result in unprecedented decline in the diversity of life. This project will help to reduce the burden placed on current and future taxonomists to identify and catalog biodiversity by introducing a set of open-source, web-based tools for identifying species from images and for measuring imaged specimens for comparative studies. These software tools will be made freely available through the publicly-funded CyVerse web platform. In addition, a system for identifying dragonflies and damselflies called ODOMATIC will be implemented on an existing web presence, OdonataCentral, allowing researchers and enthusiasts to accurately identify these insects from images of their wings. A series of free workshops will be offered in diverse urban communities in New Jersey and Alabama to increase the diversity of OdonataCentral?s user base, encourage participation in the STEM fields, and generally increase appreciation and understanding of the natural world. A series of Google Hangout events will encourage international user-ship for ODOMATIC from World Dragonfly Association members in Latin America, Africa, and Asia. In addition, undergraduate students from Rutgers University-Newark will be recruited to help in designing and training ODOMATIC, giving them valuable experience in research, programming and taxonomy.
 
This work will help to reduce the taxonomic impediment - an urgent need for more taxonomic products, like species descriptions and specimen identifications, from fewer taxonomist workers - by addressing the time-consuming, but necessary, task that is species identification. Objectives of this project include release of a newly-developed system for automatically identifying Odonata (dragonflies and damselflies) from images of their wings, which uses computer vision and machine learning to characterize and classify species.  An interface will be deployed making species identification using this system accessible through the OdonataCentral website (odonatacentral.org).  In addition, stand-alone tools will be developed for automatically describing and placing geometric morphometric landmarks on specimens in biological imagery for use in morphology-based comparative studies.  The successful completion of these objectives will benefit the odonatological community by providing dragonfly and damselfly identification.  More broadly, the tools created here will allow biologists studying other groups of organisms to rapidly extract morphological data from images of their specimens.

por.por_cntn:
Status of the North American Odonata digitization effort. Represented here are all odonate species from US and Canada. Bars represent species; clusters of bars are genera (sorted alphabetically); rows are families; progress bars are the number of ♀ (red) and ♂ (blue) scans we've made out of 10 for each species.

Representation of most of the dragonfly and damselfly wings digitized under the TOWD Project, sorted taxonomically.

Confusion matrix showing the accuracy of the Odomatic wing-based species classification. The system is currently trained to distinguished between 92 species of North American dragonflies and damselflies and is approximately 81% (20% of individuals are randomly held out for testing the system?s accuracy, causing results to vary slightly between runs). Rows represent the true species identity of individuals and columns are the species label assigned by the classification system, thus the diagonal of the matrix represents correctly-classified test individuals and incorrectly classified individuals are represented in the off-diagonal. 

Visual comparison of wing shape across flight strategies in Libelluloidea. In this example, we visualize the contours of the forewings (red) and hindwings (blue) of libelluloid dragonflies whose genera have been loosely categorized by flight strategy (individuals within percher genera spend a majority of their active time on a perch, fliers spend most of their active time on the wing, and individuals in intermediate genera are variable). Each line represents a single individual and contours have been rescaled to the same width to demonstrate broad trends in wing shape.


 

The overall goal of this work was to digitize several large collections of Odonata (dragonflies and damselflies) and to create a digitization workflow and software tools to facilitate the study of this fascinating and important group of organisms. Under this grant, we created the Targeted Odonata Wing Digitization (TOWD) Project, a multi-institutional effort to digitize all dragonfly and damselfly species in North America. We have now imaged nearly 7,000 dragonflies and damselflies from 5 collections, representing over 500 species from across North, Central, and South America. For North America, we our digital library contains representatives of 360 (77%) of the 466 species, including 76 species for which at least 10 males and 10 females have been digitized. To facilitate this effort, we have developed an efficient digitization pipeline that utilizes the CyVerse cyberinfrastructure platform, which is funded by NSF. We have also developed two open-sourced software tools that make use of the image library: Odomatic, for automatically identifying odonate species by their wings, and Odometric for measuring dragonfly and damselfly wings and making comparative analyses.

This grant has also funded an overhaul of OdonataCentral (https://www.odonatacentral.org/), a repository for images and information about dragonflies and damselflies of the Western Hemisphere and ultimate host for ODOMATIC. Programmers at Birds in the Hand who developed the accompanying DragonflyID app have created a new OdonataCentral website that will be launched by the end of 2019. A beta version of the website is available at https://oc.staging.birdsinthehand.com/. The website was built from the ground up giving it a fresh, new modern interface that improves the user experience dramatically. The mapping interface now allows a number of new and useful tools to aid users in visualizing the data. Vastly expanded filtering capabilities have also been added allowing users to better drill down on the data they need. Additionally, there is the ability to easily import records from iNaturalist, the most successful citizen science platform currently available. The data from OdonataCentral will be distributed to both GBIF and iDigBio aggregators. All of these features have also been developed with the ultimate goal of hosting and integrating ODOMATIC into the website. 

Under this grant, 13 undergraduate students participated in various aspects of the project, including field work, digitization, measuring specimens, etc. In addition, 2 postdocs have been trained under this grant. This work has been disseminated through 5 presentations and 1 poster, of which 4 presentations were made at international conferences. Information about the TOWD Project, as well as links to resources is available at the project website (https://willkuhn.github.io/towd/).
